name: Your family tree
description:
Güyük Khan was one of the __grandsons__ of [Genghis Khan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Family_and_descendants_of_Genghis_Khan#Diagrammatic_family_tree). One of his __first cousins__, Kublai Khan, was the founder and first emperor of the Yuan dynasty. And Temür Khan,  one of his __first cousins twice removed__, was the second emperor of that dynasty.

In this kata, you will receive a node connected to a family tree. You'll be that node and your task will be to explore the tree and give the correct relationship label to all the other members of your family, according to their sex and the rules specified in the next section.

---

## Rules

- __Your direct descendants__:
  - your direct descendants are your children, then the children of your children, and so on
  - the labels are, respectively:
    - _son_, _grandson_, _great-grandson_, _great-great-grandson_, and so on 
    - _daughter_, _granddaughter_, _great-granddaughter_, _great-great-granddaughter_, and so on

- __Your siblings__:
  - your siblings are your brothers and sisters
    - the labels are _brother_ and _sister_

- __Your nieces and nephews__:
  - your nieces and nephews are the direct descendants of your siblings
  - the labels are, respectively:
    - _nephew_, _grandnephew_, _great-grandnephew_, _great-great-grandnephew_, and so on
    - _niece_, _grandniece_, _great-grandniece_, _great-great-grandniece_, and so on

- __Your direct ascendants__:
  - your direct ascendants are your father and mother, then their father and mother, and so on
  - the labels are, respectively:
    - _father_, _grandfather_, _great-grandfather_, _great-great-grandfather_, and so on
    - _mother_, _grandmother_, _great-grandmother_, _great-great-grandmother_, and so on

- __Your aunts and uncles__:
  - your aunts and uncles are the siblings of your direct ascendants
  - the labels are, respectively:
    - _uncle_, _granduncle_, _great-granduncle_, _great-great-granduncle_, and so on
    - _aunt_, _grandaunt_, _great-grandaunt_, _great-great-grandaunt_, and so on

- __Your cousins__:
  - your cousins are the direct descendants of your aunts and uncles
  - your cousins have __always a prefix__ and __not always a suffix__
    - __prefix__:
      - the prefix is given according to the aunt or uncle they are a direct descendant
        - all the direct descendants of your aunts / uncles are your __first__ cousins
        - all the direct descendants of your grandaunts / granduncles are your __second__ cousins
        - all the direct descendants of your great-grandaunts / great-granduncles are your __third__ cousins
        - and so on
      - the possible prefixes are : _first_, _second_, _third_, _fourth_, and so on
    - __suffix__:
      - the suffix gives information about the generation distance between you and your cousin:
        - __if you are in the same generation__ in the family tree (at the same level in the tree), __there isn't a suffix__
        - if there is one level between you and your cousin, he is your cousin __once removed__
        - if there are two levels between you and your cousin, he is your cousin __twice removed__
        - and so on
      - the possible suffixes are : _once removed_, _twice removed_, _three times removed_, _four times removed_, and so on
  - so the labels of any of your cousin has one of the two forms : __[prefix] cousin__ or __[prefix] cousin [suffix]__
    - the following labels are valid for cousins:
      - _first cousin_, _first cousin once removed_, _second cousin three times removed_, _second cousin_

## Input

A structure representing a person connected to a family tree. Each person in the family tree has the following fields:
- __id__ : a unique integer
- __label__ : a string
  - that string will be empty for all the nodes but you. For you, it will be set to "me"
  - that's the field you should mutate to the correct relationship label
- __parent__ : the person who is the father or the mother of the person
  - if a person is at the root of the family tree, that field will be set to what corresponds to `null` in the language you use
- __children__ : a sequence of people, possibly empty
- __sex__ : a character, either 'm' for male or 'f' for female

````if:python
In Python, the structure is the following dataclass:
```python
@dataclass
class Person:
    sex         : str
    parent      : Optional['Person'] = None
    children    : list
    label       : str = ''
    id          : int
```
````
````if:javascript
In JavaScript, the structure is the following Person object:
```javascript
const Person = {
  id      : 0,
  sex     : 'm',
  label   : '',
  parent  : null,
  children  : [],
};
```
````
````if:java
In Java, the structure is the following class Person:
```java
public class Person{

    public Person parent;
    public int id;
    public final Character sex;
    public final Person[] children;
    public String label = "";
}
```
````
~~~if:scala
In Scala, the structure is the following case class Person:
```scala
final case class Person(
  var id: Int, val sex: Char,
  var parent: Option[Person] = None,
  var label: String = "",
  var children: Seq[Person] = Seq()
  )
```
~~~

## Output

Nothing in particular, you should mutate the input in this kata.

## Errors and messages

```if:python
- Input: the code of the tree, so that you can reproduce it locally
```
- Actual: a representation of your solution, with only the relevant fields (`id`, `sex`, `label`)
- Expected: same as above, but for the expected result


## Tests

- 6 fixed tests

- Random tests:
  - 100 small tests: max 3 generations and max 3 children by person
  - 100 medium tests: max 5 generations and max 4 children by person
  - Big tests according to the language you use: between 10 and 100 tests with max 9 generations and max 5 children by person

---

Happy coding, and so on, respectively.
